articles.headline: In College, Learning About Money
articles.snippet: College students often enter the real world with little knowledge of financial basics. Champlain College is trying to correct that.
articles.abstract: College students often enter the real world with little knowledge of financial basics. Champlain College is trying to correct that.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt.

articles.headline: Massachusetts Ruling on Foreclosures Is a Warning to Banks
articles.snippet: The ruling voided two foreclosures, putting the nation’s banks on notice that foreclosures cannot be based on improper or incomplete paperwork.
articles.abstract: The ruling voided two foreclosures, putting the nation’s banks on notice that foreclosures cannot be based on improper or incomplete paperwork.
articles.lead_paragraph: The highest court in Massachusetts ruled Friday that U.S. Bancorp and Wells Fargo erred when they seized two troubled borrowers’ properties in 2007, putting the nation’s banks on notice that foreclosures cannot be based on improper or incomplete paperwork.

articles.headline: The Crisis That Isn’t Going Away
articles.snippet: Europe seems unable to convince investors that it has the money and the will to address the causes of its sovereign debt problems.
articles.abstract: Europe seems unable to convince investors that it has the money and the will to address the causes of its sovereign debt problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON

articles.headline: Flex Time Flourishes in Accounting Industry
articles.snippet: Experts say some firms are especially respectful of the work-life balance, and they are retaining valuable employees as a result.
articles.abstract: Experts say some firms are especially respectful of the work-life balance, and they are retaining valuable employees as a result.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the peak season for the nation’s accounting firms begins, David Leeds’s team at Ernst & Young is once again bracing for two months of 60-hour weeks auditing the books of a major bank in Atlanta.

articles.headline: The Handwritten Letter, an Art All but Lost, Thrives in Prison
articles.snippet: Prisoners are stripped of almost all individual possessions. Writing to magazines, one of the few things they can call their own, can provide comfort.
articles.abstract: Prisoners are stripped of almost all individual possessions. Writing to magazines, one of the few things they can call their own, can provide comfort.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the Georgia Department of Corrections he is inmate No. 544319, in prison on a five-year sentence for drug possession. But to the editors of Maxim, he is Mike Bolick, a faithful reader and regular letter writer who has loopy penmanship and an eye for beautiful cover models.

articles.headline: Under Siege in War-Torn Somalia, a Doctor Holds Her Ground
articles.snippet: Dr. Hawa Abdi helps nearly 100,000 people at her medical facility, persevering despite an attack by militants in May.
articles.abstract: Dr. Hawa Abdi helps nearly 100,000 people at her medical facility, persevering despite an attack by militants in May.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia
articles.byline: By Mohamed Ibrahim and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: Obama the Centrist Irks a Liberal Lion
articles.snippet: Robert B. Reich, the former labor secretary, is disappointed in President Obama, and contends he has been unwilling to duel with an emboldened G.O.P.
articles.abstract: Robert B. Reich, the former labor secretary, is disappointed in President Obama, and contends he has been unwilling to duel with an emboldened G.O.P.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif.  So how would he grade President Obama’s economic policies, and the new team put in place this week?

articles.headline: Rift in Arizona as Latino Class Is Found Illegal
articles.snippet: The state declared the Tucson Unified School District’s Mexican-American program illegal, even while similar programs for black, Asian and American Indian students were left untouched.
articles.abstract: The state declared the Tucson Unified School District’s Mexican-American program illegal, even while similar programs for black, Asian and American Indian students were left untouched.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON  The class began with a Mayan-inspired chant and a vigorous round of coordinated hand clapping. The classroom walls featured protest signs, including one that said “United Together in La Lucha!”  the struggle. Although open to any student at Tucson High Magnet School, nearly all of those attending Curtis Acosta’s Latino literature class on a recent morning were Mexican-American.

articles.headline: Obama’s Top Aide a Tough, Decisive Negotiator
articles.snippet: William M. Daley is expected to bring his discipline and critical eye to his new job at the White House.
articles.abstract: William M. Daley is expected to bring his discipline and critical eye to his new job at the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Nobody got fired  at least, not outright  when William M. Daley arrived in Nashville in the summer of 2000 to impose order on Al Gore’s foundering presidential campaign. Aides were bickering, the candidate seemed demoralized and strategy sessions had deteriorated into what Chris Lehane, a Gore adviser, called a “salon-like atmosphere” of endless talk and no decisions.

articles.headline: In Wider War in Afghanistan, Survival Rate of Wounded Rises
articles.snippet: More helicopters, heavily armored vehicles and emphasis on the use of tourniquets have helped to save troops.
articles.abstract: More helicopters, heavily armored vehicles and emphasis on the use of tourniquets have helped to save troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHAKREZ DISTRICT, Afghanistan  Intensified fighting and a larger troop presence in Afghanistan in 2010 led to the highest American combat casualties yet in the war, as the number of troops wounded by bullets, shrapnel and bombs approached that of the bloodiest periods of the war in Iraq.

articles.headline: Iraqi Cleric Embraces State in Comeback Speech
articles.snippet: To a rapturous welcome, the populist Iraqi cleric Moktada al-Sadr delivered his support for an Iraqi state that he had once derided as a tool of the United States.
articles.abstract: To a rapturous welcome, the populist Iraqi cleric Moktada al-Sadr delivered his support for an Iraqi state that he had once derided as a tool of the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAJAF, Iraq  To a rapturous welcome that conflated the religious and political, the populist Iraqi cleric Moktada al-Sadr delivered his support on Saturday for an Iraqi state he had once derided as a traitorous tool of the United States and that his followers had battled in the streets of Iraq’s most important cities only a few years before.

articles.headline: U.S. Subpoenas Twitter Over WikiLeaks Supporters
articles.snippet: The subpoena is the first public evidence to surface of a criminal investigation of disclosures of classified information by WikiLeaks and its founder.
articles.abstract: The subpoena is the first public evidence to surface of a criminal investigation of disclosures of classified information by WikiLeaks and its founder.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Prosecutors investigating the disclosure of thousands of classified government documents by the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks have gone to court to demand the Twitter account activity of several people linked to the organization, including its founder, Julian Assange, according to the group and a copy of a subpoena made public late Friday.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and John F. Burns

articles.headline: $2.6 Billion to Cover Bad Loans: It’s a Start
articles.snippet: A deal won’t recoup much for taxpayers, but it may open the door to a reckoning of liabilities created by banks’ questionable mortgage practices.
articles.abstract: A deal won’t recoup much for taxpayers, but it may open the door to a reckoning of liabilities created by banks’ questionable mortgage practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANK investors cheered the announcement last week that Bank of America would pay $2.6 billion to buy back mortgages it had improperly sold during the housing bubble to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the beleaguered mortgage finance giants. It seemed a sweet deal for the bank, whose Countrywide Home Loans unit had peddled tens of billions of dollars in risky loans to the taxpayer-owned companies.

articles.headline: In Attack’s Wake, Political Repercussions
articles.snippet: A suspect was in custody and a second was being sought after Representative Gabrielle Giffords was wounded and John M. Roll, a federal judge, was killed.
articles.abstract: A suspect was in custody and a second was being sought after Representative Gabrielle Giffords was wounded and John M. Roll, a federal judge, was killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — Representative Gabrielle Giffords, an Arizona Democrat, and at least 17 others were shot Saturday morning when a gunman opened fire outside a supermarket where Ms. Giffords was meeting with constituents.
articles.byline: By Marc Lacey and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Southern Sudan Feels Freedom Close at Hand
articles.snippet: After decades of war, southern Sudan is at the moment it has been yearning for with a vote on independence.
articles.abstract: After decades of war, southern Sudan is at the moment it has been yearning for with a vote on independence.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUBA, Sudan — Philip Geng Nyuol started fighting for independence with his hands.

articles.headline: Is Law School a Losing Game?
articles.snippet: Law schools’ rosy statistics say most graduates are working. The problem is, many aren’t working as lawyers, or making enough to pay back their student loans.
articles.abstract: Law schools’ rosy statistics say most graduates are working. The problem is, many aren’t working as lawyers, or making enough to pay back their student loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF there is ever a class in how to remain calm while trapped beneath $250,000 in loans, Michael Wallerstein ought to teach it.

articles.headline: Facing Scrutiny, Banks Slow Pace of Foreclosures
articles.snippet: Investigations into the way banks foreclose on delinquent homeowners have contributed to a sharp slowdown.
articles.abstract: Investigations into the way banks foreclose on delinquent homeowners have contributed to a sharp slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  An array of federal and state investigations into the way banks foreclose on delinquent homeowners has contributed to a sharp slowdown in foreclosures across the country, especially in hard-hit cities like this one.

articles.headline: Bloodshed Puts New Focus on Vitriol in Politics
articles.snippet: The shooting of Representative Gabrielle Giffords focused attention on the degree to which inflammatory language has become a steady undercurrent in the nation’s political culture.
articles.abstract: The shooting of Representative Gabrielle Giffords focused attention on the degree to which inflammatory language has become a steady undercurrent in the nation’s political culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The shooting of Representative Gabrielle Giffords and others at a neighborhood meeting in Arizona on Saturday set off what is likely to be a wrenching debate over anger and violence in American politics.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Kate Zernike

articles.headline: Evidence Points to Methodical Planning
articles.snippet: Officials said that evidence seized from Jared L. Loughner’s home indicated that he had intended to kill Gabrielle Giffords, who was still in critical condition.
articles.abstract: Officials said that evidence seized from Jared L. Loughner’s home indicated that he had intended to kill Gabrielle Giffords, who was still in critical condition.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — Prosecutors charged Jared L. Loughner, a troubled 22-year-old college dropout, with five federal counts on Sunday, including the attempted assassination of a member of Congress, in connection with a shooting rampage on Saturday morning that left six people dead and 14 wounded.

articles.headline: A Sacrifice to Appease NPR’s Gods
articles.snippet: NPR fires a commentator. NPR receives 23,000 e-mails about said firing. An NPR executive resigns. But will one sacrifice appease the angry gods?
articles.abstract: NPR fires a commentator. NPR receives 23,000 e-mails about said firing. An NPR executive resigns. But will one sacrifice appease the angry gods?
articles.lead_paragraph: A long time ago, a kingdom was beset by tempestuous storms, and it was decided that one of the most prized citizens would be fed to the volcano as a sacrifice to appease the punishing gods. After the sacrifice was made and the crowd exulted, a young visitor turned to the man next to him and asked if this ritual always worked. “Nah,” said the local. “Does wonders for morale, though.”

articles.headline: Pentagon Must ‘Buy American,’ Barring Chinese Solar Panels
articles.snippet: A defense spending bill tailored to benefit many nations at China’s expense could mar President Hu Jintao’s visit to the United States next week.
articles.abstract: A defense spending bill tailored to benefit many nations at China’s expense could mar President Hu Jintao’s visit to the United States next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The military authorization law signed by President Obama on Friday contains a little-noticed “Buy American” provision for the Defense Department purchases of solar panels — a provision that is likely to dismay Chinese officials as President Hu Jintao prepares to visit the United States next week.

articles.headline: Small Leak Shuts Down Oil Pipeline in Alaska
articles.snippet: A small oil leak that shut down the Trans Alaska Pipeline System poses a threat to BP’s reputation and fortunes while raising the possibility of a short-term increase in oil and gasoline prices.
articles.abstract: A small oil leak that shut down the Trans Alaska Pipeline System poses a threat to BP’s reputation and fortunes while raising the possibility of a short-term increase in oil and gasoline prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  A small oil leak at a pumping station has shut down the Trans Alaska Pipeline System, which could lead to higher oil and gasoline prices in the short term and deliver a new blow to the reputation and fortunes of the British oil giant BP.

articles.headline: A TV-Internet Marriage Awaits Blessings of All Parties
articles.snippet: The future of cable and satellite distributors may hinge on how they handle the union of television and the Internet.
articles.abstract: The future of cable and satellite distributors may hinge on how they handle the union of television and the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  The blending of television and the Internet is inevitable. But will it happen in concert with the major cable and satellite distributors, or in spite of them?

articles.headline: Suspect’s Odd Behavior Caused Growing Alarm
articles.snippet: Jared L. Loughner’s weird laughter and aggressive outbursts at a community college worried students and instructors alike.
articles.abstract: Jared L. Loughner’s weird laughter and aggressive outbursts at a community college worried students and instructors alike.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — In a community college classroom here last June, on the first day of the term, the instructor in Jared L. Loughner’s basic algebra class, Ben McGahee, posed what he thought was a simple arithmetic question to his students. He was not prepared for the explosive response.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson, Serge F. Kovaleski, Dan Frosch and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: A Single, Terrifying Moment: Shots Fired, a Scuffle and Some Luck
articles.snippet: In the Tucson shooting, chance saved some and put others in harm’s way.
articles.abstract: In the Tucson shooting, chance saved some and put others in harm’s way.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON  Patricia Maisch was waiting in line to get a picture with her congresswoman, Gabrielle Giffords, when gunfire erupted. Blood was spilling onto the pavement in an atmosphere of panic and pandemonium. The gunman was walking towards her, shooting people along the way. “I thought I was next,” she said.

articles.headline: 1986 Privacy Law Is Outrun by the Web
articles.snippet: Many Internet companies and consumer advocates say that the main law governing communication privacy is outdated.
articles.abstract: Many Internet companies and consumer advocates say that the main law governing communication privacy is outdated.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Concerned by the wave of requests for customer data from law enforcement agencies, Google last year set up an online tool showing the frequency of these requests in various countries. In the first half of 2010, it counted more than 4,200 in the United States.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Facebook Wins Relatively Few Friends in Japan
articles.snippet: As Goldman Sachs pours $450 million into Facebook, Japan, with a large and growing online advertising market, is a big hole in Facebook’s global fabric.
articles.abstract: As Goldman Sachs pours $450 million into Facebook, Japan, with a large and growing online advertising market, is a big hole in Facebook’s global fabric.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Mark Zuckerberg. Who?

articles.headline: Belarus Signals It Could Seize Opponent’s Son
articles.snippet: The government says it is investigating the status of 3-year-old Danil Sannikov after the arrest of his parents, Andrei Sannikov, a former presidential candidate, and Irina Khalip, a journalist.
articles.abstract: The government says it is investigating the status of 3-year-old Danil Sannikov after the arrest of his parents, Andrei Sannikov, a former presidential candidate, and Irina Khalip, a journalist.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus  Ever since riot police officers crushed a large protest against apparent fraud in presidential elections here last month, the security services  still called the K.G.B. in this authoritarian former Soviet republic  have been rounding up people across the country for even the most tangential affiliation with the opposition.

articles.headline: Film Studio Born of Comic Books Grabs Hollywood’s Attention
articles.snippet: Barry Levine’s company is tapping into and helping shape a new business identity for production companies.
articles.abstract: Barry Levine’s company is tapping into and helping shape a new business identity for production companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Ask Barry Levine, an upstart movie producer and comic book publisher, what he is working on, and he will stare you in the eye and start peeling off his shirt. There, tattooed on his shoulder, is a large image of Hercules.

articles.headline: Shooting Suspect Waives Bail and Is Ruled ‘a Danger’
articles.snippet: Jared L. Loughner agreed not to contest his continued imprisonment but offered no hint of how he would respond to the charges.
articles.abstract: Jared L. Loughner agreed not to contest his continued imprisonment but offered no hint of how he would respond to the charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  Jared L. Loughner, his head shaved bare and his hands and feet in restraints, was led Monday into a federal courtroom, where he agreed not to contest his continued imprisonment but offered no hint of how he would respond to the murder and attempted murder charges linking him to the Tucson shootings that left six dead and 14 injured.
